title: 106_s485
content: The "Urban Homestead Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Key definitions are provided in Section 2. In this Act, key definitions are provided including terms like community development corporation, low-income families, multifamily housing project, Secretary, and severe physical problems. Severe physical problems in a housing unit include lack of hot or cold water, malfunctioning heating system, no electricity, exposed wiring, blown fuses, and dark public hallways. The term "single family residence" refers to a 1- to 4-family dwelling held by the Secretary. A multifamily housing project is considered "substandard" if at least 25 percent of the units have severe physical problems. The term "unit of general local government" has the same meaning as in section. The term "unoccupied multifamily housing project" refers to a multifamily housing project certified by the Secretary as uninhabited. SEC. 3. DISPOSITION OF UNOCCUPIED AND SUBSTANDARD PUBLIC HOUSING. The Secretary must publish a list of unoccupied and substandard housing projects owned by them every 6 months in the Federal Register, with exceptions for recently acquired projects. The Secretary must publish a list of unoccupied and substandard housing projects owned by them every 6 months in the Federal Register, with exceptions for recently acquired projects. Upon request, the Secretary will transfer ownership of unoccupied or substandard multifamily housing projects to community development corporations. The Secretary will transfer ownership of unoccupied or substandard multifamily housing projects to community development corporations located in the same area, after satisfying any incurred indebtedness. The Act exempts property disposition requirements from the Multifamily Housing Property Disposition Reform Act of 1994. It also ensures that existing tenant leases remain unaffected. The Secretary is required to establish necessary procedures within 6 months of the Act's enactment.
